{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Every integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 2k, k \in \mathbb{Z} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = 2k+1, k \in \mathbb{Z} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (even and odd numbers)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we square both forms, we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ( 2k )^2 = 4k^2 = 4a+0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a = k^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
  
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" ( 2k+1 )^2 = 4k^2+4k+1 = 4 \left( k^2+k \right) +1 = 4b+1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b = k^2+k "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the square of an even number is always divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the square of an odd number is always one more than a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            A square number can be written as, if even, (2c)^2 and odd as (2c+1)^2.
Divinding by 4 we get:
(2c)^2/4 = c^2    => zero remainder
(2c+1)^2/4 = (4c^2+4c+1)/4  => we can see that in this case we obtain 1 as remainder.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the remainders of such numbers after dividing by 16.  A quick check tells us that perfect squares are always congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \color{#20A900} 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} 14 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}14 \ \ \color{#333333} \text{mod} \ 16  \\ 144 &\equiv \ \ \color{#20A900}0 \\ 1,444 &\equiv \ \ \color{#20A900}4 \\ 14,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \\ 144,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \\ 1,444,444 &\equiv \color{#D61F06}12 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10,000 = 16 \times 625 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so every number from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 14,444 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on is congruent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4,444 \equiv \color{#D61F06}12 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" mod 16, and thus not a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[This train of thought was inspired by Henry U factoring out "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^2 = 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and then considering divisibility by 4.]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Look up "},{"type":"text","text":"modular arithmetic","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":".  There are only 16 possible remainders when you divide by 16: 0, 1, 2, ..., 14, 15.  Just look at the squares of those numbers (so the perfect squares from 0 to 225) and see what the remainders are when dividing by 16.  It doesn't take too long, and you see a lot of repeated values."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0^2 = \ \ 0 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 0 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} \ \ 8^2 = \ \ 64 = 16 \times \ 4 + \color{#20A900} 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1^2 = \ \ 1 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 1 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} \ \ 9^2 = \ \ 81 = 16 \times \ 5 + \color{#20A900} 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^2 = \ \ 4 = 16 \times 0 + \color{#20A900} 4 \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \color{#333333} 10^2 = 100 = 16 \times \ 6 + \color{#20A900} 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since any number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is even, it must be the square of an even number, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444 = (2k)^2 = 4k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In our case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"144 = 12^2 = (2\cdot 6)^2 = 4\cdot 36"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444 = 38^2 = (2\cdot 19)^2 = 4\cdot 361"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now let's take a look at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" numbers "},{"type":"text","text":"with more than two","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits: by dividing any such number by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", in fact "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{{\color{#0000ff}{144}}4\ldots 444}{4} = \frac{{\color{#0000ff}{1440\ldots 000}}}{4} + \frac{4\ldots 444}{4} = {\color{#0000ff}{360\ldots 000}} + 1\ldots 111 =  {\color{#0000ff}{36}} 1\ldots 111 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an odd number, thus it must be the square of an odd number, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111 = (2l+1)^2 = 4l^2 + 4l +1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By rearranging we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 110 = 4l^2 + 4l = 4(l^2 + l)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i.e. any number on the left must be a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; but any such number must be divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", thus it must have the last two digits divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which in our case is never true for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Summing up: we have just proven that any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"361\ldots 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (with "},{"type":"text","text":"two or more","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits) can't be the square of an integer number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (see first line), so the answer is that there are "},{"type":"text","text":"no other","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1444\ldots 444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that are perfect squares."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=10a+2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 10000b^2+2400b+144 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", implying that the 3rd digit from the right in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is odd. The only possibility satisfying the pattern is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 = 144"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=1000000c^2+2×1000×462×c+213444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1.2.2) Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=1000c+962"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For both these cases there is no solution because the digit at position 4 from the right is odd (and it cannot be the leading 1 since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 > 1444"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Summarizing: The only solution for possibility 1) is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x=12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) Suppose x ends on an 8, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=10a+8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" x ends on 38 or 88"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.1.1) if x ends on 038, the 4th position from the right is odd so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=38"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the only solution."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I wanted to put emphasis on a common misuse of the AM-GM inequality on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + a^4 + b^8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":": "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since a, b are positive, 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + a^4 + b^8 \geq 3 \times \sqrt[3]{a^4 b^8} = 3(a b^2)^{\frac{4}{3}} = 3 \times 5^{\frac{4}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Equality occurs when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = a^4 = b^8 = 5^{\frac{4}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  But "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = 5^{\frac{4}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a contradiction.  So while "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \times 5^{\frac{4}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents a lower bound on the expression, it does "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\underline{not}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a minimum."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Instead, apply the AM-GM Inequality on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^4 + b^8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^4 + b^8 \geq 2 \times \sqrt[2]{a^4 b^8}= (a b^2)^{2} = 2 \times 5^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Equality occurs when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^4 = b^8 = 25 \Rightarrow a = \sqrt[2]{5}, b = \sqrt[4]{5} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"min(a^4 + b^8) = 50 \Rightarrow min(1 + a^4 + b^8) = 1+ 50 = \boxed{51}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (which I should note is greater than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \times 5^{\frac{4}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b^2=\dfrac 5 a. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ b^8=\left(\dfrac 5 a \right)^4.\\
f(a)=1+a^4+\left(\dfrac 5 a \right)^4, ~~ f '(a)=0 \implies ~~ a=\sqrt 5.\\
f "(a)>0, ~~ so ~ ~~~ a=\sqrt 5. ~ is ~ min.\\
f(a)_{min}=1+(\sqrt 5)^4+\left(\dfrac 5 {\sqrt 5} \right)^4=\Large \color{#D61F06}{51}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{32}+\sqrt{18}-\sqrt{50}=?"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Factor the terms inside the square root sign in terms of perfect squares."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt{16(2)}+\sqrt{9(2)}-\sqrt{25(2)}=4\sqrt{2}+3\sqrt{2}-5\sqrt{2}="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#EC7300}\large\boxed{2\sqrt{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\large\color{#20A900}answer}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sqrt{32} + \sqrt{18} - \sqrt{50}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle = \sqrt{4^2 \times 2} + \sqrt{3^2 \times 2} - \sqrt{5^2 \times 2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle = 4\sqrt{2} + 3\sqrt{2} - 5\sqrt{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle = 2\sqrt{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the "},{"type":"text","text":"British Flag Theorem","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", we have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^2+x^2=4^2+7^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=16+49-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2=64"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
